Project Description  The Project is an immediate response to help the Government 
address  serious,  recurring  floods.  The  project  design  is  thus 
based  on  least-cost  flood  mitigation  measures  coupled  with 
assistance  to  help  the  Government,  through  an  associated 
technical assistance (TA), identify and initiate medium- to long-
term comprehensive flood management. 
The Project will provide (i) structural measures comprising least-
cost feasible solutions to protect villages and agricultural land on 
the Araz, Ganikh, and Mazim rivers against floods, which occur on 
average once in 10 years, and to protect other areas against 
floods, which occur on average once in 50 years; (ii) nonstructural 
measures constituting pilot community-based afforestation, flood 
forecasting  and  warning,  and  flood  zoning;  (iii)  disaster 
preparedness  and  flood  fighting  for  organizations,  physical 
facilities, and residents through capacity building and procurement 
of  operation  and  maintenance  equipment;  and  (iv)  project 
management and monitoring. The Project will cover 25 schemes 
in  12  districts  in  the  four  flood-prone  areas  inhabited 
predominantly by the poor. Poverty incidence in the project areas 
is 63% compared to 49% nationwide. 
 
Rationale  Many areas are vulnerable to floods. They cause loss of life and 
property and reduce income-earning opportunities. Impacts are 
exacerbated by the inability of rural populations to afford personal, 
crop, and livestock insurance. Floods worsen living standards of 
the poor, negate any progress in reducing poverty, and can cause 
the  non-poor  to  fall  into  poverty.  Without  protection  from 
floodwaters, the whole rural asset base is at risk in certain areas. 
Floods  not  only  threaten  settlements  but  also  leave  layers  of 
sediment  over  agricultural  land,  seriously  diminishing  its 
productivity.  Water  resources  control  and  management  are, 
therefore, the critical factors underlying efforts to promote rural 
growth and raise rural incomes. Improved protection provided by 
the  Project  will  not  only  secure  assets  but  will  also  allow 
development of knowledge to minimize flooding.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Republic  of  Azerbaijan  for  the  Flood  Mitigation  Project.  The  report  also  describes 
proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Supporting  River  Basin  and  Flood  Management 
Planning, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated 
to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  At the request of the Government of Azerbaijan, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
approved a TA1 to prepare a flood mitigation project. The project preparatory TA (PPTA) was 
carried out from February to August 2003. This document is based on consultants’ reports; 
missions’  findings;  and  discussions  with  concerned  government  agencies,  potential  project 
beneficiaries, and other external funding agencies. The project framework is in Appendix 1.  
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
3.  Azerbaijan has a population of 8.11 million, which grows at 0.38% per annum. About 
56% lives in urban areas and 44% (about 3.6 million people) in rural areas. Life expectancy is 
72 years and the adult literacy rate is 97%. 
4.  From independence in 1991 to 1995 the country experienced considerable political, 
social, and economic instability, one result of which was about 1 million refugees and internally 
displaced persons. Gross domestic product (GDP) in 1995 was only 44% of the 1990 level, and 
household  expenditures  declined  by  50%.  In  1995  the  Government,  with  the  help  of  the 
International  Monetary  Fund  and  World  Bank,  initiated  several  programs  to  achieve 
macroeconomic stabilization, structural adjustment, and resumption of economic growth. These 
programs terminated direct credits and have successfully stabilized the economy. The budget 
deficit has been reduced to less than 2% of GDP, borrowing costs cut to 7%, and inflation rate 
reduced to 2% per annum. GDP has increased in seven successive years and is now higher 
than in 1990. Foreign exchange reserves amount to $1.2 billion. 
5.  ADB2 notes that the economy continued its strong growth in 2002, mainly due to a 
rebound in foreign domestic investments in the oil sector. Since output growth resulted primarily 
from  an  increase  in  productivity,  wages  and  salaries  rose  substantially,  while  employment 
increased only marginally. The average wage rose by 20.3% in nominal terms (17.1% in real 
terms), while unemployment is reported to have increased from 1.2% at end-2001 to 1.3% at 
end-2002. Results of recent labor market and household budget surveys, however, suggest that 
despite the impressive economic growth of recent years, the actual unemployment rate remains 
at 15.8% (14.2% among men; 18.6% among women). Average per capita income is $700.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
6.  Sector  Context.  The  Government’s  poverty  reduction  strategy4  has  a  number  of 
elements designed to make income distribution equitable. The oil sector will not have much 
impact on rural income levels, and growth opportunities must be created in the non-oil sector. 
The agriculture sector is the primary engine of rural growth but is highly dependent on water 
resources control and management. Under Azerbaijan’s climatic and topographic conditions, the 
ability to manage water resources effectively and efficiently largely determines sector output and 
productivity levels. Without well-managed irrigation facilities, crop yields have been halved, and 
without appropriate drainage systems, soils have become salinized and unable to grow crops. 
Crop production is highly dependent upon irrigation. Water losses are even higher than in the 
Soviet period, when they averaged 50% of supplies. Higher withdrawals per hectare (ha) are 
needed to make up for these losses, which, in turn, overburden systems and accelerate their 
deterioration. Drainage systems were never adequately developed, and salinization appeared 
quickly after irrigation networks spread in the 1970s–1980s. As drainage systems failed, the 
extent of heavily salinized areas doubled in the late 1990s. Tens of thousands of hectares have 
been  retired  in  Azerbaijan  because  they  no  longer  yield  crops.  A  detailed  water  sector 
assessment is in Appendix 2. 
7.  Rural  infrastructure  has  deteriorated  markedly  in  recent  years,  resulting  in  reduced 
access  to  services,  lower  agricultural  productivity,  and  a  greater  risk  of  flood  damage  to 
settlements and crops. While investment in physical infrastructure such as roads, irrigation and 
drainage, potable water supply, power supply, telecommunications, and marketing facilities is 
essential to underpin rural growth strategies, investments in flood management are vital not only 
to protect these facilities and the associated settlement and agricultural lands but also to create 
a secure environment to attract more investments. Thus, the Project will greatly facilitate rural 
and agriculture sector growth and ensure that rural populations gain secure livelihoods and 
access to essential services. 
8.  Flood Management. Floods generally occur in spring and early summer and are caused 
by snowmelt combined with heavy rainfall. Flooding is particularly acute in the greater Caucasus 
area, which is traversed by a series of hill torrents with steep slopes, causing high velocities and 
huge amounts of bed-material movement. The catchment areas of these hill torrents vary from 
less than 50 square kilometers (km2) to 350 km2, except for Goychay (1,480 km2). These hill 
torrents  are  generally  dry  or  have  insignificant  flow  during  the  non-flooding  season.  The 
topography and hydrologic conditions of these hill torrents do not support feasible reservoirs to 
attenuate their short-lived flood peaks. The Araz and Ganikh, however, are perennial rivers with 
catchment areas of more than 50,000 km2 each. They have multipurpose reservoirs built across 
them and drain into the Kur River. Samur, another perennial river, has a catchment area of 
3,620 km2. All rivers of Azerbaijan drain into Caspian Sea. 
9.  Major floods occurred in 1988, 1997, 1999, and 2002. Disastrous damage in the greater 
Caucasus area affected public buildings, 82 human settlements with a population of 246,000, 
138,000 ha of cultivated area, 38 kilometers (km) of highway, 22 km of power line, 95 km of gas

10.  Many areas are vulnerable to floods. They cause loss of life and property, and flood 
damage reduces income-earning opportunities. Impacts are exacerbated by the inability of rural 
populations to afford personal, crop, and livestock insurance. Flood protection is particularly 
important as the bulk of the rural population living in flood-prone areas has been rendered poor 
because of loss of assets and has little capacity to rebound after losses. Thus, floods worsen 
living standards of the poor, negate any progress in reducing poverty, and can cause the non-
poor to fall into poverty. Poor implementation of protected watershed area regulations results in 
illegal tree cutting and overgrazing, leading to heavy sediment loads after floods, seriously 
diminishing agricultural productivity. Individuals and communities are also unwilling to invest in 
flood-prone areas. 
11.  In 1990 Azerbaijan adopted a national strategy for flood protection based entirely on 
structural  measures.  The  approach  to  flood  management  is  so  limited  because of  lack  of 
coordination among agencies and absence of an interministerial coordination body.6 Because of 
deep  involvement  in  structural  measures,  Azerbaijan  has  gained  invaluable  experience  in 
designing and constructing flood protection walls, and many, particularly those close to major 
cities, have been properly designed, constructed, and maintained and are still serving their 
purpose.  However,  examples  of  poor  construction  and  neglected  maintenance  are  also 
numerous, and the huge fleet of machinery for river channeling and flood fighting has not been 
recouped during the last couple of decades and is suffering from inefficiency, reduced capacity, 
and increased operational costs. The inhabitants of flood-prone areas consider structures and 
channelization as the most reliable flood protection measures. 
12.  The country has no concept of flood zoning. A law7 restricts encroachment on waterways 
and water bodies but only to protect water quality. Afforestation in watersheds—1,500–3,000 ha 
annually nationwide—consists mainly of tree planting and is not done specifically to promote 
sustainability, reduce erosion, or improve the watershed hydrologic characteristics. The country 
has no flood forecasting system, and the unreliable, ineffective flood warning system is based 
on  voice  communication  from  some  ill-equipped  and  poorly  managed  hydrometeorological 
stations. 
13.  “Do nothing” is clearly not the least-cost option and not acceptable. Leaving settlements 
and croplands at risk has political, economic, and social consequences. Politically, such a 
strategy would only highlight how rural communities receive fewer services and less attention 
than urban communities. Economically, analysis of the project area concludes that the likely 
average annual cost of damage is about $4.83 million. Added to this cost is the foregone 
investment that would be made in the absence of risk to assets.  
14.  Relocating  settlements,  agricultural  lands,  and  infrastructure  is  neither  socially 
acceptable nor economically feasible. In many parts of the world, watershed management has 
proved effective in improving rivers’ hydrologic characteristics, including reducing flood peaks

16.  Institutional Context. The key agency associated with flood management is the State 
Amelioration and Irrigation Committee (SAIC), which manages all irrigation, drainage, and flood 
control infrastructure and activities. SAIC has a number of departments that design, implement, 
and manage various aspects of water resources. However, the departments work in isolation, 
and an institutional arrangement to facilitate integrated water resources management is lacking. 
The Government has thus requested ADB’s assistance in this regard. 
17.  An irrigation systems department (ISD), subordinate to SAIC and the local government, 
controls operation and maintenance (O&M) of irrigation and flood protection facilities in each 
district.  However,  a  more  holistic  view  of  flood  management  incorporating  nonstructural 
measures requires the involvement of other agencies such as the Ministry of Ecology and 
Natural Resources (MENR) and its National Meteorological Department (NMD) as well as the 
participation of affected communities. The Government has established the State Commission 
for Emergency Situations to deal with disasters such as floods and drought but not to coordinate 
flood prevention or warning. 
18.  SAIC’s  2003  budget  is  about  $32.0  million,  of  which  about  $1.8  million  has  been 
allocated for flood protection in project districts, local staff salaries, equipment maintenance and 
use,  and  flood  damage  repairs.  Allocation  is  about  50–60%  of  actual  requirements.  The 
Government does not charge specific fees for flood protection. Even for irrigation and drainage 
systems, the irrigation service fee covers less than 5% of SAIC’s total irrigation and drainage 
budget.8 The low level of cost recovery is part of the Government’s policy to keep costs of 
agriculture and irrigation to the farmers to a minimum until they can afford to gradually start 
paying higher fees. The Government has no plans to directly recover project investments from 
the beneficiaries. 
19.  Government Plans and ADB Operational Strategy. The State Program on Poverty 
Reduction and Economic Development, approved in February 2003, identified a number of 
priorities  to  help  promote  economic  growth,  create  jobs,  and  reduce  poverty.  Particular 
importance is attached to creating jobs in the non-oil rural and agriculture sectors, which are 
considered promising. However, they need investment in physical infrastructure such as roads, 
irrigation systems, potable water supply, power supply, telecommunications, flood protection, 
and produce-marketing facilities. ADB’s interim operational strategy is fully consistent with these 
priorities in its support for rural development and emphasis on physical infrastructure.

20.  Policy Dialogue. During project processing, the Government agreed to move away from 
the  traditional  approach  of  structural  measures  for  flood  protection  and  to  consider  flood

21.  External Assistance. The World Bank is the lead agency in irrigation and drainage, 
drinking  water  supply  and  sanitation,  and  environmental  protection.9  Appendix 3  provides 
information  on  major  external  assistance  related  to  the  sector.  Other  multilaterals  include 
Kreditanstalt fủr Wiederaufbau (KfW), Islamic Development Bank, and European Union. The 
United States Agency for International Development (USAID), Organization for Security and 
Cooperation in Europe, and North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) have supported regional 
watershed management. Some external funding agencies have also provided ad hoc assistance 
for construction and rehabilitation of flood structures. ADB’s proposed loan would be the first 
systematic  assistance  to  reduce  flood  risk  and  simultaneously  provide  synergy  to  the 
investments by the other key agency, the World Bank.  
22.  Lessons Learned. International experience suggests that floods are most effectively 
addressed using an optimal combination of structural and nonstructural measures. Structural 
measures are used worldwide as the most effective immediate protection from floods, and 
Azerbaijan has invaluable experience in designing walls to protect against hill torrents under a 
variety of flow and sediment load conditions. The importance of sound watershed management 
has  been  established  in  a  number  of  ADB’s  project  performance  audit  reports.  Many 
communities have experienced increasing and severe flooding after storms or prolonged rain 
partly due to denuded forested uplands and watersheds. Similarly, the sector synthesis of post-
evaluation findings in the irrigation and rural development sectors pointed out how lack of proper 
watershed  management  endangers  irrigation  and  rural  development  projects.10  Flood 
forecasting and warning systems have established their usefulness during the last few decades 
and are now being used to efficiently operate water resources systems of Bangladesh, India, 
Malaysia,  Pakistan,  Peoples’  Republic  of  China,  Philippines,  and  a  number  of  other  ADB 
member countries. Flood zoning is now an integral part of land-use planning in most developed 
countries and is becoming increasingly popular among developing countries. Post-evaluation 
experience  in  flood  control  recommends  strengthening  integrated  river  basin  management. 
Experience  of  ongoing  World  Bank-financed  projects  in  Azerbaijan  suggests  that  projects 
should (i) focus on one or few major activities; (ii) be flexible; and (iii) foster understanding and 
participation of all stakeholders, particularly beneficiaries. Projects are generally on schedule 
and cover areas in Sharur and Gusar, where local agencies’ capacity has been found to be 
strong. 
23.  The  Project  has  been  designed  on  the  basis  of  experience  of,  and  lessons  from, 
Azerbaijan and other countries. First, the overall design represents a balance between structural

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Objective 
24.  The  project  objective  is  to  immediately  and  systematically  improve  security  against 
recurring floods in selected areas. The Project will establish and support sustainable flood 
management  infrastructure,  plans,  and  practices,  and  thus  significantly  reduce  recurring 
economic losses and help increase household incomes and improve living standards in the 
project area. About 63% of project area beneficiaries11 are below the poverty line. The Project is 
expected to reduce the incidence of poverty to 57%.  
25.  The project design thus focuses on least-cost flood mitigation measures coupled with 
tangible assistance through an associated TA (para. 62) that will help the Government identify 
and initiate medium- to long-term comprehensive flood management. 
26.  Starting with a list of 67 candidate flood protection schemes, the Government narrowed 
them down to 27 for PPTA, excluding the floodplains already protected by embankments and 
reservoirs, and the ones with committed funds. The consultant excluded from further study two 
schemes as they were downstream of a reservoir being constructed to have enough capacity to 
absorb their flood peaks. For the remaining 25 schemes, the consultant confirmed the feasibility 
of providing flood protection using the criteria of historical damage, type and extent of threat, 
and potential for improvement. Thus, the Project will cover 25 schemes in 4 flood-prone areas in 
12  districts:  1  scheme  in  the  Araz  River  floodplain  in  Sharur,  Autonomous  Republic  of 
Nakhchivan; 22 in 9 districts in the greater Caucasus area in the northwest; and 1 each in Gusar 
in the northeast and Astara in the southeast. While the greater Caucasus area is well known for 
flooding, the other three areas, although isolated, offer strong justification, including higher 
economic  returns,  for  their  inclusion  in  the  Project.  Sharur,  important  for  its  agricultural 
production and as a link for trade with Turkey, is threatened by floods from the Araz. Likewise, 
Astara is an important trade link with Iran, and floods from the Astara River threaten the safety 
of the bridge on the highway leading to Iran. Flood protection in the Samur River in Gusar is 
justified to protect water resources projects funded by the World Bank and Islamic Development 
Bank. Project districts are shown on the map.

1.  Structural Measures 
28.  The  25  schemes  comprise  the  least-cost  feasible  solutions  to  protect  villages  and 
agricultural lands near the Araz, Ganikh, and Mazim rivers against floods occurring  on average 
once in 10 years, and in other areas against floods occurring on average once in 50 years. The 
structures’ height has been determined by providing a suitable freeboard over the estimated 
flood water level. The proposed measures will protect 5 major towns and 43 villages, covering 
76,790 ha and inhabited by 215,250 people. 
29.  On  the  Araz,  which  runs  through  a  floodplain,  flood  protection  consists  of 
rehabilitation/construction of a 30 km embankment, with stone pitching in 10 km reaches which 
are under direct threat of erosion by an active channel too close to the embankment. 
30.  In the case of hill torrents, structures consist of the shortest feasible protection walls, 
varying from 50 to 2,690 meters (m) long and generally on one side of the active channel to 
protect specific areas without constricting the flow, altering the flow regime, or aggravating 
flooding upstream or downstream. Protective structures include concrete gravity walls, stone 
concrete walls, reinforced concrete walls, and stone filling. Selection of the type of structure for 
a specific location was based on the least-cost solution, considering slope, velocity, discharge, 
quantity, and size of the hill torrents’ bed load, and availability of construction materials. All 
together, the 38 protection walls in 22 schemes in 11 districts are 23.0 km long, while stone 
filling will be provided at two locations over 4.2 km.

2.  Nonstructural Measures 
32.  Nonstructural  measures  constitute  watershed  management,  flood  forecasting  and 
warning, and flood zoning. 
a.  Watershed Management 
33.  Degradation of the catchments because of poor management during the last couple of 
decades has led to higher flood peaks and larger sediment loads. To introduce afforestation as 
a tool for long-term flood management, gully stabilization, and sediment control, the Project will 
set up a pilot scheme for community-based afforestation of 550 ha of degraded areas in the 
catchment of Kishchay hill torrent, where agroclimatic conditions are favorable and communities 
and the implementing agency are already familiar with and involved in government-financed 
afforestation. Some nurseries have species suitable for planting in the pilot area. Of the 550 ha, 
275 ha will involve rehabilitation, and 275 ha, new afforestation. MENR’s Forestry Development 
Department (FDD) will be the subcomponent’s implementing agency. The afforestation target 
has been limited to 550 ha, keeping in view the 4-year implementation period, and the fact that 
this is the first project of its type in the country. FDD, with project consultants’ guidance, will 
develop a community-based afforestation program, including nursery management. As trees 
take a long time to grow, subcomponent benefits by the end of implementation are difficult to 
quantify. Nonetheless, lessons and experience from this pilot project will be useful and can be 
replicated in FDD’s afforestation program and any future externally financed project. The total 
subcomponent cost is estimated at $250,000.

b.  Flood Forecasting and Warning 
34.  Azerbaijan  has  no  flood  forecasting  system,  and  the  flood  warning  system  is  less 
effective because of the absence of meteorological stations at 2,000–2,500 m altitude, and 
many stations and telemetric network do not function. To develop flood forecasting, improve 
district administrations’ warning capability, and facilitate earlier warning, the Project proposes to 
rehabilitate eight and establish five new meteorological stations in the catchment of the project 
hill  torrents  and  telemetrically  connect  them  to  their  respective  district  offices.  The 
meteorological stations to be rehabilitated include Nakhchivan, Zagatala, Alibay, Sheki, Gabala, 
Ismailly, Quba, and Astara. They will be provided with barographs, hydrographs, thermographs, 
electronic barometers, and telemetric systems. The new stations will also be equipped with 
telemetric systems for automatic transmission of data and will be built at 2,000–2,500 m altitude 
in  the  catchments  of  Mazimchay,  Katekchay,  Talachay,  Kurmukhchay,  and  Kishchay  hill 
torrents. NMD will help prepare specifications for procurement, evaluate the bids, and install the 
stations. They will be integrated into the NMD network for O&M. Using hydrometeorological data 
collected from the network and an ADB-financed TA (para. 62), a suitable flood-routing model 
will  be  selected  to  forecast  floods  and  guide  reservoir  operations.  The  total  cost  of  this 
subcomponent is estimated at $250,000. 
c.  Flood Zoning 
35.  Flood zoning is an important nonstructural measure, which, with hardly any investment 
in physical infrastructure, helps minimize damage even from extreme flooding. ADB proposes 
that the Government issue a resolution defining flood zones (such as prohibitive, restrictive, and 
warning zones) and specifying land uses for each. SAIC will run an information campaign to 
raise public awareness of the hazards associated with land uses that violate the resolution’s 
regulations. SAIC will also be required to demarcate flood zones for each of project area 
river/hill torrent, considering existing land uses. To highlight the importance of flood zoning to 
manage floods, the Government agreed to issue the resolution as a condition for loan effectivity. 
The Government also agreed to submit to ADB a time-bound action plan to implement flood 
zones in the project area rivers/hill torrents within 1 year of loan effectivity. SAIC will work 
closely on flood zoning with ISDs, State Committee for Land and Cartography, and MENR.

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Expected Impacts 
1.  Economic Analysis 
63.  The  Project  will  enable  communities  to  break  out  of  the  cycle  of  periodic  asset 
replacement and move many households above the poverty line by diminishing the risk and, 
consequently, the losses from flood damage, and enhance development opportunities (e.g., 
higher cropping intensities) as a result of a more secure environment. Out of 76,790 ha, about 
43,515 ha inhabited by 215,250 people comprising 44,350 households will directly benefit from 
the Project.

15 
64.  The economic analysis is based on measurable benefits, which relate primarily to the 
annualized cost of averted flood damage. The Project will prevent average annual loss of $4.83 
million.  Improved  protection  will  also  allow  further  development  because  the  risk  to  such 
development  from  flooding  is  minimal.  Enhanced  development  possibilities  have  not  been 
analyzed in detail. Nonetheless, the key elements and their order of magnitude deduced from 
the situation in adjacent but less vulnerable areas indicate that these investments will result in 
unmeasured  project  benefits  at  least  equal  to  those  that  have  been  measured.  Economic 
analysis  of  the  Project  has  been  undertaken  based  on  constant  2003  prices  and  price 
relativities, and using techniques that measure public investment efficiency. Economic costs and 
benefits were estimated using border prices for inputs and outputs. Where appropriate, these 
prices have been prepared using World Bank commodity prices for May 2003. Local costs were 
estimated using financial data adjusted by the appropriate conversion factors. 
65.  The  most  widely  applicable  conversion  factor  used  in  the  analysis  is  the  standard 
conversion factor, which represents the ratio of all prices in the domestic economy to their 
international comparators. Using the weighted average of import and export tariffs, excluding 
subsidies, the standard conversion factor has been calculated as 0.95. The other important 
conversion factor is the shadow wage rate. In rural areas underemployment is significant and 
wage-earning employment highly seasonal. Therefore, the opportunity cost of unskilled labor is 
considered to be lower than the market rate. The shadow wage rate is estimated at 75% of the 
market rate. Skilled labor in rural areas has a higher market rate, and wage rates are much 
firmer due to the shortage of technical skills outside urban centers. For skilled labor a standard 
conversion factor of 0.95 has been applied. 
66.  Project benefits (averted flood damage) have been estimated in a number of steps. First, 
the  types  of  assets  that  have  been  and  are  likely  to  be  damaged  were  divided  into  five 
categories: crops, housing, infrastructure, other physical assets, and indirect damage. Potential 
damage levels against flood design parameters for each category were determined per hectare  
and then aggregated to give a composite value per hectare for all types of damage. Second, the 
per hectare value was multiplied by the estimated protected area to give a total value of 
potential damage against flood design parameters for each scheme and for the Project as a 
whole. The third step was to calculate the average annual cost of damage, taking into account 
flood frequency. Finally, the aggregate annual cost of damage (benefits) is matched against the 
economic costs and an economic internal rate of return (EIRR) obtained from the net benefit 
stream. 
67.  The economic costs of project implementation have been derived from financial costs, 
taking into account that (i) interest during construction, price contingencies, and taxes and 
duties  were  excluded;  and  (iii)  local  financial  costs  were  converted  to  economic  costs  by 
applying the relevant conversion factors. EIRRs were calculated for each scheme and for the 
Project as a whole. Individual EIRRs range from 13.3% to 49.2%. Only six out of 25 schemes 
have an EIRR below 15%, and one below 12%. These schemes have been retained because (i) 
they are a part of a cluster and their omission would be unfair, (ii) the EIRR shortfall is marginal 
and far outweighed by unmeasured benefits, and (iii) the schemes are small and the overall 
project EIRR remains extremely robust. The base-case EIRR for the whole Project is 20.3%. 
This  base  case  has  been  tested  against  cost  overruns,  reduced  benefits,  and  delayed 
implementation. A 10.0% increase in costs reduces the EIRR to 18.2%. A 10.0% reduction in 
the price of wheat reduces the EIRR to 19.4%, and a 10.0% reduction in benefits reduces it to 
18.0%. The EIRR is reduced to 12% when investment costs rise by 53% or benefits fall by 35%. 
A combination of 10.0% increase in costs and 10.0% reduction in benefits reduces the EIRR to

16 
 
16.1%. Thus, the project EIRR is resilient to the most likely causes of lower-than-expected 
performance. Economic analysis details are in Appendix 13. 
2.  Poverty Impacts and Social Development Strategy 
68.  In the project area, flooding is an important source of vulnerability. An estimated 215,250 
people will directly benefit from the Project through avoided damage to 44,350 houses on 
43,515 ha. About 79% of the population receives less than $1 per day per capita per month, 
63% have incomes below the official poverty line of $0.80 per day. About 16% of the population 
earns only $0.20 more than those officially classified as poor. A flood can easily erode this 
incremental income and make this segment of the population poor. The quantifiable benefits—
average annual avoided damage of $4.83 million—translate to 16% of average annual per 
capita income and 6% of the annual per capita poverty threshold. The Project will also benefit 
the poor through reduced damage to personal property, and protection of livelihood sources. 
Based on income distribution data from the household budget survey and the projected increase 
in incomes due to the Project, 6.4% of the population will benefit from increased income and 
clear the poverty threshold. The Project is thus conservatively estimated to reduce poverty 
among  beneficiaries  from  63%  to  57%  and  protect  16%  of  the  non-poor  population  from 
becoming poor. The summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 14 while the 
social and poverty impact assessment is in Supplementary Appendix I. 
69.  The participatory approach was initiated during project design and is an ongoing activity 
that will be further strengthened during project implementation. Participatory activities prioritize 
the interests of the poor, women, and vulnerable groups. Community management is envisioned 
for watershed management and flood protection structure maintenance, and will be facilitated by 
community  training  and  community-based  organization  formation.  Contractors  will  hire 
community residents, with appropriate representation from the poor and women, and provide 
them with skills to maintain the Project. 
70.  The  Project  will  provide  direct  and  indirect  benefits  to  the  poor  and  vulnerable 
population13 primarily through avoided loss to life and property, damage resulting in reduced 
income-earning opportunities, and foregone opportunities. Women will benefit through reduced 
flood-related work, project jobs, and improved living standards. The Project is estimated to 
generate 359,000 person-days of unskilled labor and will ensure employment of poor residents 
and equal opportunities and pay for women. The community watershed management program 
will train residents, and raise their awareness of the need, to protect the watershed. The Project 
will facilitate the formation of community-based organizations for watershed management and 
flood  protection  structure  maintenance.  The  Project  will  not  affect  indigenous  peoples  or 
affordability of goods and services.

72.  The proposed structures will be constructed along the rivers/hill torrents on government 
property and so the Project will not be engaged in land acquisition. The Project, through various 
flood management measures, will help reduce human, property, livelihood, and environmental 
damage. The Project will have a positive impact on the project area environment particularly on 
terrestrial habitats, by improving flood control capacity, reducing flood damage, and enhancing 
the local environment and institutional capacity for flood control. The hill torrents bring debris 
during floods, covering vast areas and destroying valuable croplands. While protecting these 
croplands, the proposed structures will not obstruct river flows or flooding of unprotected, mainly 
waste, land. Therefore, the measures are not likely to significantly reduce the benefits of floods 
such as groundwater and wetland recharge, and addition of soil nutrients to wasteland, which 
serves as pasture. Afforestation in the watershed of Kishchay hill torrent will help check soil 
erosion,  stabilize  gullies,  reduce  silt  load,  and  improve  hydrologic  characteristics  of  the 
watershed, and thus have a long-term positive environmental impact on the watershed and 
downstream areas. Flood zoning will also develop awareness regarding safe land use for 
different geographic areas and thus lay the foundation for proper and secure land use, which 
will have a long-term beneficial impact. 
73.  Considering that the project works are generally small and widespread, and that skilled 
and  nonskilled  labor  is  available  locally,  construction  camps  will  generally  be  small. 
Nonetheless, attention will be paid to social discipline, education, and control and safeguards in 
wastewater and solid waste disposal. Erosion of unconsolidated material in areas with bare soil, 
such  as  embankments  and  construction  sites,  will  be  controlled  by  planning,  staged 
construction, and revegetation to minimize areas that are exposed to rainfall for any length of 
time. Careful planning and enforcement of quality control procedures during construction will 
ensure protection of workers’ health, avoidance of accidents, and control of environmental 
pollution by noise and dust. 
74.  As per recommendation of the IEE, an M&E unit will be established in the PMO which, 
among other tasks, will implement an environmental monitoring program and recommended 
mitigation measures (para. 39). Adequate O&M measures must be used to control negative 
environmental impacts. The Project has been designed not to have any negative impacts on the 
environment, and none have been identified. The Government has assured implementation of 
the environmental management plan (EMP) developed during project processing, and mitigative 
measures described in the IEE. A summary of environmental analysis is in Appendix 15. The 
summary IEE and EMP are in Supplementary Appendixes E and F respectively. 
B.  Resettlement 
75.  Protection  structures  will  be  on  the  banks  of  hill  torrents  or  rivers  and  have  been 
designed to avoid involuntary resettlement. Hill torrents do not have water year-round and are 
not used as a resource in daily life. Project design ensures that structures will be built in areas 
not used for residential or livelihood purposes and will have no impact on access or movement. 
In perennial rivers, design of new protection structures has avoided potential displacement. No 
squatters live on government land where structures will be located. PPTA consultants confirmed

during their visits to each site that structures will be built on government land, and no land 
acquisition is envisaged.15 
C.  Risks and Safeguards 
76.  The project design has taken into account a number of risk factors whose potential 
economic impact has been assessed as part of the economic sensitivity analysis. All have been 
shown to have modest adverse consequences. The main risks are those that could delay 
implementation and benefits. The implementation schedule has been programmed to allow for 
possible disruption due to flooding. Although floods are short, key works will not be scheduled 
when flooding is a high probability. The mild winters do not normally halt construction activity, 
but heavy snowfall may slow down construction in some schemes.  
77.  The Project has completed a significant amount of preparatory work. Subprojects have 
been prepared to feasibility-level designs and packaged to implement many small individual 
schemes in parallel. The project preparatory unit’s tasks include advance procurement action 
(para. 49), which will ensure avoidance of initial implementation delays. 
78.  A  further  risk  is  that  project  activities  may  not  be  fully  supported  locally.  PPTA 
consultants thus worked closely with local agencies to select schemes and decide the nature of 
flood mitigation measures. Local authorities welcomed the Project as it will relieve them of a 
huge logistical burden. Finally, the risk of inadequate O&M of project facilities is addressed 
through (i) minimal O&M requirements of the concrete structures; (ii) development of strong 
beneficiary ownership for the structures through an information awareness campaign that will 
facilitate early detection of potential problems and beneficiaries’ undertaking minor O&M on their 
own; (iii) provision of O&M equipment; and (iv) government assurances regarding allocation of 
adequate O&M budget, and proper and timely maintenance of the structures.

WATER SECTOR ASSESSMENT 
A.  Water Resources Assessment 
1.  Available Water Resources 
1.  Azerbaijan  is  a  downstream  country  within  the  river  basins  that  supply  its  water 
resources. Only 30% of the country’s available water supply is generated inside its borders. 
Available water resources average around 32.1 cubic kilometers (km3) per year, with high inter-
year variability. The largest rivers, the Kur and Araz, account for around 80% of total resources, 
and  their  catchment  area  covers  80%  of  the  country.1  Fresh  groundwater  reserves  are 
estimated at 4.2 km3. Substantial portions of available water resources are stored in reservoirs 
(total capacity of which is approximately 21 km3). The major reservoirs are committed to multiple 
uses, chiefly irrigation and hydropower, and also serve as buffers against droughts such as 
2002. Abundant rainfall in 2002 necessitated emergency releases, flooding the lower reaches of 
the Kur-Araz basin. 
2.  Surface water quality is extremely poor, in part owing to upstream industrial pollution. 
The annual discharge of pollution from Georgia into the Kur-Araz basin averages 265 million 
cubic  meters.  The  Kur  and  Araz  also  carry  considerable  sediment  (estimated  at  60,000 
milligrams/liter at their confluence). Groundwater quality is generally adequate except in coastal 
areas where rising sea levels have increased the salinity of aquifers. 
2.  Utilization 
3.  Water withdrawals have grown by almost 25% since 1975, to around 16.5 km3 per year, 
suggesting that  only  51%  of  available  resources  are  withdrawn  annually.  Abstraction  from 
surface sources comprises around 90% of water withdrawals. Withdrawals are expected to rise 
by a further 25% in the foreseeable future. Agriculture accounts for 70% of water withdrawals, 
followed by industry (25%) and households (5%).  
4.  Agriculture contributes approximately 20% of gross domestic product (GDP) and 41% of 
employment. The command area of irrigation systems is around 1.45 million hectares (ha), 75% 
of which is gravity fed and the balance in pumped systems. Most irrigated land is in the Kur-
Araz basin, which also contains regions with a shortfall in drainage infrastructure. As irrigation 
and drainage infrastructure has been inadequately maintained since independence, conveyance 
losses are estimated at 50–70%. Substantial areas went out of cultivation as irrigation systems 
collapsed; the cultivated area in 2001 was 900,000 ha, of which 80% was planted to wheat or 
cotton. In 1999–2001 collective and state farms were broken up into 815,000 farm families, not 
all of whom can take full advantage of existing canals and drains. 
5.  Industry contributes 33% to GDP and 7% to employment. Industrial use of water is 
mostly for electricity generation, cotton processing, and canning enterprises. Rivers provide 
91% of water used by industry; groundwater, 4%; and the Caspian Sea, 5%. Only 6% of 
industrial water supply is drawn from on-site sources. Around 50% of households are served by 
piped water, principally in Baku and secondary cities. The quality of piped water supplied

6.  A high percentage of water resources is committed to multiple uses—a potential source 
of conflict. Agriculture and hydropower have directly conflicting demands upon water resources. 
Daily interruptions in electricity supply and a shortage of spare parts hinder the operation of 
pump systems (nearly 25% of the total). Pollution from industries and drainage from cropland 
worsen  water  quality  of  aquifers  and  wells.  Other  sectors’  impact  has  eliminated  90%  of 
spawning grounds, while pollution threatens fish stocks. Shipping in inland waterways has 
virtually ceased to exist. 
7.  Water-use  efficiency  in  all  sectors  is  low.  High  conveyance  losses  suggest  that 
agricultural water withdrawals per hectare could be reduced by rehabilitating infrastructure and 
management. Industrial enterprises could reduce their water consumption by an estimated 30–
50% by reequipping and establishing sound management practices. Domestic water distribution 
systems are rundown and water losses estimated at up to 50%. 
B.  Water Resource Management  
8.  Azerbaijan  has  signed  numerous  international  agreements  concerning  water-related 
issues, in particular with Iran and Russia. However, joint management of international water 
resources has been complicated by the hostile relationship between Azerbaijan and Armenia. 
These  neighboring  countries  have  established  contacts  with  each  other  via  Georgia  to 
cooperate on technical issues. 
1.  Legal Framework 
9.  Since independence, the country has started to address requirements for improved 
national water management, which include ownership of infrastructure and concept of payment 
for use of water resources. Water management institutions are required to implement a cost 
recovery policy and empowered to deny supply to nonpaying customers. However, the legal and 
regulatory  framework  has  several  weaknesses,  including (i)  legislation  and  regulations  are 
developed  ad  hoc;  (ii)  lacunae  exist,  for  example,  concerning  the  legal  responsibility  for 
multipurpose dams; (iii) the legislative process is prone to influence from vested interests; (iv) 
many laws, regulations, and acts do not ensure adequate transparency and remain vague and 
subject to manipulation by officials; and (v) little of the legal and regulatory framework is widely 
available to, and recognized by, the general public. 
2.  Institutional Responsibilities 
10.  A number of national institutions are involved in separate aspects of water resources 
management. However, national formal procedures to plan and coordinate water resources 
management are lacking—a weakness the Government recognizes. 
11.  Irrigation  and  Drainage.  The  most  powerful water  management  body  is  the  State 
Amelioration and Irrigation Committee (SAIC), which manages the government-owned irrigation 
and drainage infrastructure and supervises almost all irrigation and flood control activities. An 
irrigation  system  department  (ISD),  subordinate  to  SAIC,  operates  in  each  district  and  is 
responsible  for  water  delivery.  SAIC’s  operations  are  extremely  centralized  and  its 
organizational structure is outdated. The average irrigation water service charge is equivalent to 
$0.60 per thousand cubic meters. However, charges cover only 10–15% of the cost of operation

and  maintenance  (O&M).  SAIC  has  been  successful  in  fee  collection;  in  1998–2001  the 
percentage of paying customers rose substantially, from 25% to 73%. The principle of cost 
recovery is not applied to flood control structures. 
12.  Domestic Water Supply. The management of domestic water supply is shared by 
several  organizations,  primarily  51  district  utility  for  water  and  sewerage  operations  and 
maintenance operating outside of Baku, and the Apsheron Regional Water Company, which 
supplies  water  to  greater  Baku.  Rural  communities  sometimes  supply  their  own  water  in 
conjunction with a local government. Water-pricing techniques used by the district utility for 
water and sewerage operations and maintenance, introduce substantial distortions by not, for 
example, adequately accounting for the cost of debt service, uncollected revenue, maintenance 
expenditures,  or  depreciation.  Under  the  tariff  structure,  industrial  enterprises  subsidize 
households. Fee collection of water utilities is poor. 
13.  Hydropower Generation. Hydropower is managed under the auspices of Azenergo 
(under the Ministry of Fuel and Energy). Azenergo is responsible for O&M and capital repairs of 
infrastructure on hydroelectric dams. The day-to-day management of Azenergo is centralized in 
the same manner as SAIC. 
14.  Environmental Aspects. The Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources has regulatory 
responsibility  for  numerous  aspects  of  water  management,  including  natural  resource 
management, pollution and water quality monitoring, and hydrometeorology.  
15.  Disaster Response. At the national level, response to disasters, including flood and 
drought,  is  the  responsibility  of  the  ad  hoc  State  Commission  for  Emergency.  Similar 
commissions are established within local governments when necessary. Revision of the system 
for  crisis  management  has  begun  with  assistance  from  the  United  Nations  Development 
Programme (UNDP). 
16.  Local Government. Local government plays a significant role in water management. 
The heads of local governments are almost always consulted before the appointment of the 
head of a local branch of a national institution. Local governments have formal authority over 
water utilities. 
3.  Instruments and Resources for Management 
17.  Data collection and monitoring are fragmented and underfunded, with results rarely 
shared. Planning often proceeds as before, utilizing outdated standards and norms. Financial 
control is often lax, accounting remains based upon old standards, and application of financial 
instruments such as water charges is nascent. Institution leaders are often unsuited to the new 
demands being placed upon them, and most lack managerial acumen and have a weak service 
orientation. 
4.  Government Flood Mitigation Strategy and Targets 
18.  In upland areas spring, snowmelt, and rainfall cause hill torrents, some of which cause 
highly destructive localized flash floods. The Government estimates the annual cost of such 
damage at around $9 million. No comprehensive strategy for flood management exists. It would 
benefit infrastructure, including transport and communications.

C.  Support to the Water Sector 
19.  The  World  Bank  is  the  leading  agency  in  the  water  sector,  with  approved  loans 
equivalent to $131 million to irrigation and drainage, urban drinking water supply and sanitation 
and environmental protection, and $45 million more in the lending pipeline. Other multilateral 
agencies have financed infrastructure construction and rehabilitation. 
20.  The ADB is supporting the Government’s State Program on Poverty Reduction and 
Economic Development and has initiated the poverty reduction partnership process. ADB will 
develop  a  country  operational  strategy  emphasizing  (i)  integrated  and  sustainable  water 
resource  management,  including  enhancing  stakeholder  participation;  (ii)  improvement  of 
financial efficiency and sustainability of water sector institutions; and (iii) working with local 
people to maintain the natural environment. Developing policies, institutional frameworks, and 
capacities of central and local governments and communities to apply these principles will be 
accorded  a  high  priority.  Specifically,  ADB’s  sector  operational  strategy  might  include  the 
following elements: 
(i)  Promote a national focus on water sector reform. Support the creation and 
effective operation of a neutral apex organization to provide national leadership 
in water sector reforms, including policy and legislation. 
(ii)  Foster integrated management of water resources. Support the introduction 
of  management  on  the  basis  of  river  basins  or  main  hydraulic  units  as 
appropriate. 
(iii)  Foster water conservation and service delivery improvement. Rehabilitate 
irrigation and drainage infrastructure to return land to cultivation and raise rural 
incomes. Improve urban systems to reduce household and business expenditure 
and improve health. 
(iv)  Improve system efficiencies. As public sector service provision is inefficient 
and unsustainable, systems are deteriorating. Adopt market principles to pursue 
efficiencies, but temper them to ensure the rights of the poor to water. 
(v)  Promote regional cooperation. Coordinate closely with neighboring countries 
to protect Azerbaijan’s regional water interests. 
(vi)  Improve governance. Establish viable public private sector partnerships based 
on decentralized management in water service provision organizations. Study the 
relationship between poverty and poor water management, not least so that 
investment impacts can be properly assessed. 
21.  Within this framework, future investments, to be confirmed and defined, will be governed 
by the need to (i) provide potable water and irrigation to the rural population; (ii) mitigate the 
impacts of flash floods and hill torrent erosion, including protection of the upper reaches of 
tributary basins; (iii) provide assistance after natural disasters; (iv) provide controlled drainage of 
arable  lands;  (v)  respond  to  local  water  management  priorities;  and  (vi)  help  mitigate 
groundwater pollution.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The  Project  will  provide  flood  protection  measures  to  the  towns  of  Ganikh,  Sheki, 
Gabala, Goychay, and Ismailly, and 43 villages, with a total population of about 215,250. Of the 
25 schemes, 22 are along the southern slopes of the greater Caucasus mountains in the north 
of  the  country,  which  is  drained  by  the  Ganikh  River  and,  subsequently,  Kur  River.  The 
remaining three schemes are on the Samur River along the border with Russia, on the Araz 
River in Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic, and on the Astara River in the southeast. The total 
area protected from flooding will be 76,790 hectares (ha). The structural features will be a 
combination  of  embankments  (about  30  kilometers  [km])  and  different  types  of  stone  and 
concrete walling (about 23 km). 
B.  Approach to Economic Analysis 
2.  Project  economic  analysis  was  undertaken  using  techniques  to  measure  public 
investment efficiency. Economic costs and benefits were estimated using prices that reflect their 
real value. Major traded goods have been valued at border prices, and local costs estimated 
using financial data adjusted by the appropriate conversion factors.  
3.  The  most  widely  applicable  conversion  factor  used  in  the  analysis  is  the  standard 
conversion factor (SCF), which represents the ratio of all prices in the domestic economy to 
their  international  comparators.  Using  the  weighted  average  of  import  and  export  tariffs, 
excluding subsidies, the SCF has been calculated at 0.95. 
4.  The other important conversion factor is the shadow wage rate. Rural underemployment

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY 
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis/Poverty Partnership Agreement 
 
One of six key strategies of the Government’s State Program on Poverty Reduction and Economic Development 
(2003–2005) is to improve infrastructure for the poor. Infrastructure has been identified as a national priority in the 
draft poverty partnership agreement, which was discussed with the Government in May 2003 and will be finalized after 
confirmation of the poverty reduction targets. 
 
The Project covers 12 districts and will benefit 215,250 people (57% urban and 43% rural) in 5 towns and 43 villages. 
Of the total project area of 76,790 hectares (ha), about 43,515 ha or 57% involve settlements while remaining is the 
agricultural area. The Project will primarily reduce the vulnerability of the poor and enhance their security, particularly 
considering the lack of personal, crop, and livestock catastrophe insurance or reinsurance schemes. Floods could 
further lower living standards of the poor, negate any progress in reducing poverty, and cause the non-poor to fall into 
poverty. Physical infrastructure and nonstructural measures will protect lives; reduce damage to property, livelihood 
sources, and social services; and provide stability required for investments and economic growth.  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis  Proposed Classification: Pro-Poor 
 
While project area residents have high (although deteriorating) degrees of access to housing, basic education, and 
primary health services, high levels of unemployment and low wages result in widespread poverty. Based on the 
participatory rapid assessment and on interview surveys, 63% of the project area population is estimated to have 
incomes less than the absolute poverty threshold of AZM120,000 per capita per month (or $0.80 per person per day at 
2003 exchange rates); more than half the poor live in extreme poverty, with monthly per capita incomes below 
AZM72,000 (or $0.48 per person per day). A large proportion of the population is poor, and of the non-poor, 16% have 
incomes not exceeding 25% of the poverty line.  
 
While the implementation of the government poverty reduction strategy is expected to reduce poverty in the long term, 
the project area is highly vulnerable to floods. Particularly in the northwest, it has always been under the threat of 
floods and sediments. Over the last 10 years, of the 40 most devastating floods, 25 occurred in the project area. 
Environmental risks from flooding constitute an important source of vulnerability.  
 
The Project is expected to generate significant job opportunities and income for beneficiaries. The Project is estimated 
to generate 359,000 person-days of unskilled labor, of which at least 300,000 are envisioned to be for the poor. The 
Project will increase disposable income by reducing costs for rehabilitating personal property from flood damage. The 
Project will protect 44,350 houses and an area of 76,790 ha. Most houses (82.3%) in the affected areas are made of 
local materials, and although restoration costs are lower than the value of cement block houses (AZM43.7 million vs. 
AZM58.0 million), the probability of damage with each flood is also higher for houses made from local materials. 
Restoration depletes household savings and assets. Aside from monetary expenditures, households have opportunity 
costs from foregone economic and social activities during restoration of damaged property.  
 
Based  on  the  economic  analysis,  the  estimated  average  avoided  annual  damage  to  personal  property  and 
infrastructure is AZM23.60 billion ($4.83 million). Prevention of crop damage and loss of livestock are particularly 
beneficial to the rural poor, who depend mainly on these for livelihood. Flood protection will also reduce damage to 
important social infrastructure and prevent disruptions to vital social services such as schools, clinics, and hospitals; 
utilities such as electricity; transport; and markets. The project area has 79 kindergartens, 114 schools, 29 clinics, and 
11 hospitals that are threatened by floods. Estimated avoided damage translates to an average of AZM85,000 per 
capita per year to project beneficiaries, which is 16% of the average annual per capita income and 6% of the annual 
per capita poverty threshold.

population who receive less than AZM150,000 per capita per month (approximately $1 per person per day at 2003

preventing the non-poor from sliding to poverty.

may deposit sediment, raise the riverbed, and cause floods upstream. The proposed works are 
not expected to aggravate problems downstream. The project area has no wetlands. 
14.  Skilled and unskilled labor is available locally for construction so large-scale construction 
camps need not be established. Attention will be paid to proper collection and disposal of 
wastes, however, including construction of temporary toilets with small treatment devices, and 
sanitary pit latrines. Planning, training, and quality control will ensure workers’ health and safety, 
and minimize environmental problems such as noise, dust, waste oil, and grease. 
4.  Astara  
15.  The proposed interventions are very near international boundaries. Barbed wire on the 
Azerbaijan side limits access to the Astara Hill Torrent.  Flood protection structures will avoid 
any backwater effect that may deposit sediment, raise the riverbed, and cause floods upstream. 
The proposed works are not expected to aggravate problems downstream. The project area has 
no wetlands. 
16.  The flood protection structures will be constructed close to Astara town. Planning and 
control measures will minimize noise (no construction during night) and dust (sprinkling water in 
dry season) during construction. Skilled and unskilled labor is available locally for construction 
so large-scale construction camps need not be established. Soil erosion will not be a problem 
as works will be minor. 
E.  Institutional Requirements and Environmental Monitoring Program 
17.  A project management office (PMO) will be established within the State Amelioration and 
Irrigation Committee to manage project activities on a daily basis. A monitoring and evaluation

60  Appendix 15 
 
(M&E) unit with three staff members will be established within the PMO. One responsibility of 
the M&E unit will be to implement the environmental monitoring program, including monitoring of 
effects and compliance and checking of several key indicators to track environmental changes, 
including flooding regime, river hydrology, morphology, sedimentation, bank erosion/cutting, 
quality of river water, groundwater fluctuations, ecology, and value of life. The M&E unit will also 
monitor dust, noise, and other construction waste during project implementation. The M&E 
program will start well in advance of detailed project design for each scheme and will extend 2 
years after project completion. 
F.  Public Consultation and Information Disclosure 
18.  The project preparatory technical assistance consultants had a team of environmental 
and  community  development  specialists  who  liaised  closely  with  the  beneficiaries.  A 
comprehensive questionnaire was developed and meetings were held in May and June 2003 to 
assess the views of project area residents. The solutions of earthen embankment and stone 
pitching at various locations to check the river embankment were discussed, and the public in 
general, satisfied with these solutions, was strongly in favor of the Project. 
G.  Findings and Recommendations 
19.  The IEE screening process shows that the Project will not (i) require any resettlement, 
(ii) result in any unwarranted loss of natural ecosystems or any significant adverse impacts on 
environment, (ii) cause any additional hazards to endangered species, or (iv) increase the 
affluent-poor income gap. The Project will promote a sense of security among low-income 
project  area  residents,  significantly  reduce  flood  damage,  and  improve  the  project  area 
economy. 
H.  Conclusions 
20.  The IEE has shown that the Project will have minor adverse environmental impacts and 
how  they  can  be  kept  at  acceptable  levels  by  implementing  mitigation  measures  and  the 
monitoring program. Therefore, a full environmental impact assessment will not be required.
